posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked: Doing just a tiny bit of research, it looks like there isn’t an FRC vendor that sells the Orange PI 5. Where are you getting yours from? Is there another place/vendor except Amazone?

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: There are also other SBCs (Single Board Computers) that use the same chip. Like the Raxda Rock 5A.

posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked:
viggy96:

axda Rock 5A

From what I saw, they are much more expansive.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
Shouldn’t be.

Rockchip RK3588 64bit octa core ARM based SBC RADXA´s latest generation SBC based on the Rockchip RK3588 in a compact form factor packed with a wide range of class-leading functionality, features and expansion options. They are available in various...

Price: USD 99.00

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
Missed that the Rock 5A is also on AliExpress @GalDotan @Dave1998

https://www.aliexpress.us/item/3256806776545816.html?gatewayAdapt=glo2usa

posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked: Looks like a pretty good alternative. Did you have experience with them? Can they take standard Raspberry Pi firmware?

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
By that do you mean the OS image?

Radxa publishes Debian images here:

Introduction

posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked: Is the npu on those come from the factory or do you need an external card? the specs are a little bit unclear

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: It uses the same SoC as the Orange Pi 5 Pro, the Rockchip 3588S, so the NPU is built in. It does have an M.2 slot, which you could probably use to install a Coral TPU if you wanted.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: You definitely don’t need an external NPU. The Coral is less powerful than the built-in one anyway.

posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked: How did you power your Rock5A? In the specs it called for 12V 2A, dose it mean I can just connect it to the small ports on the PDH ?

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
I never actually used ours on a robot, we chose to use a x86 mini PC, a MinisForum UM690S. But in testing I had no issues just using a USB-PD wall adapter. And in competition, you could use a battery bank, those are allowed by the rules.

For the UM690S, we used the following voltage regulator: https://a.co/d/6AaWsO0

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: I think you need a regulated power source otherwise voltage drops from motor draw may kill your coprocessor, try a 12v 2a port on a VRM .

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Also not sure where you saw that it needs 12V, I used a 5V USB wall adapter just fine for it.

posts.name: tkchan
posts.cooked: remember for those that opt for the 5Pro, remember to disable your WLAN/Bluetooth.
